title: Vegan meat company launches products in Australia including a hotdog and a burger that BLEEDS
text:
A revolutionary vegan meat company has launched its products in Australia, including a plant-based hot dog and a burger than bleeds.

Moving Mountains will now be sold exclusively though Woolworths stores around Australia and will also be a feature at Henry's Burgers in Melbourne.

Competition in the plant-based meat sector is expected to increase, with Australia's east coast rivaling top markets for vegetarian products in London and California.

Moving Mountains will now be sold exclusively though Woolworths stores around Australia and will also be a feature at Henry's Burgers in Melbourne

A revolutionary vegan meat company has launched its products in Australia, including a plant-based hotdog and a burger than bleeds

The UK-based company was founded in 2016 by Simeon Van der Molen, The Sydney Morning Herald reported.

He started the business after he was told by a doctor that he had to cut out red meat to critically lower his cholesterol.

But when he went to the supermarket his options were scarce.

'The burgers consisted of falafels squashed into the shape of a burger. I wanted food that could be enjoyed. I wanted great tasting, juicy plant-based burgers that tasted like the real thing,' Mr Van der Molen said.

He expected the company to be profitable within its first year of trading due to the quality of product.

'We put that down to quality of product, branding and real passion in what we do and what we believe in and unwavering strength and tenacity,' he said.

Woolworths approached Moving Mountains about stocking the products and has already sent three shipments of the burgers and hotdogs.

'Woolworths is on a mission to increase their range of plant-based meats and I'm actually delighted to work with them,' Mr Van der Molen said.

The UK-based company was founded in 2016 by Simeon Van der Molen (pictured with the product)

The plant-based alternatives compete with animal meat for both taste and texture, using beetroot juice as a 'bleeding' effect.

In just two years the business has quickly grown into a $180 million empire in Europe, and expanded to the United States.

Mr Van der Molen challenges skeptics to try the hot dogs as he believes they are eerily similar to the real thing thanks to sunflower seeds.

The ingredient was an 'absolute revelation' which helped the company replicate the real thing and stand out to competitors.

'We tried with different proteins like soy, wheat and none of them were really working really well until we stumbled across sunflower seeds,' Mr Van der Molen told news.com.au.

'No one else has anything like this in the world.'
